title: 107_s1572
content: The Act may be cited as the "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001". Congress finds that full and active participants in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members, as stated in previous Acts. The prompt admission of certain countries to NATO is crucial for promoting economic stability and security in the region. Congress emphasized the importance of expanding NATO to include emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe, beyond just Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. They highlighted the potential contributions of countries like Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria to NATO's goals of enhancing stability, freedom, and peace in Europe. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join the Alliance in the first round of NATO enlargement. The NATO heads of state and government declared that further invitations would be extended to nations willing and able to meet membership criteria. At the Washington Summit in April 1999, NATO pledged to continue expanding and considering European democratic countries for membership. In April 1999, at the Washington Summit of the NATO Alliance, it was declared that NATO will continue to welcome new members who can further the principles of the Treaty and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. In late 2002, a summit in Prague, Czech Republic will decide on inviting additional emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join NATO. In May 2000 in Vilnius, Lithuania, foreign ministers discussed potential new members including Albania, Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania. In May 2000 in Vilnius, Lithuania, several Central and Eastern European countries declared their cooperation in seeking NATO membership in the next round of enlargement. President George W. Bush also emphasized the importance of security and freedom for all new democracies in Europe. President George W. Bush and former President William J. Clinton both expressed support for NATO membership for all European democracies seeking it, emphasizing the importance of security, freedom, and shared responsibilities within the alliance. Bush highlighted the need to avoid using nations as pawns and to advance the cause of freedom, while Clinton emphasized keeping NATO open to emerging democracies willing to shoulder membership responsibilities. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized in a speech in Detroit, Michigan on October 22, 1996, that NATO should remain open to all of Europe's emerging democracies willing to take on membership responsibilities, with no automatic exclusions or veto power for countries outside NATO. Clinton also stressed the importance of preventing a gray zone of insecurity in Europe. Congress reaffirms its support for NATO enlargement as expressed in previous acts and declarations, endorsing further enlargement of the alliance. It designates Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries previously designated for assistance under similar acts. Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria are eligible for assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, with the possibility of other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe also being designated for assistance. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for several countries under the Arms Export Control Act for fiscal year 2002, with specific grant amounts allocated to Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, and Romania. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Security Assistance Act of 2000.
